moves.1. e4: MM vs. Team Checkmate.  White wins both games, black loses both--match draw.
moves.5. dxc3 c6 6. Ne3 Bc5 7. b4 Bxe3 8. Bxe3: Had white taken the queen with the rook it would be out on the D file and white would retain the castling option.
moves.9... f6 10. g3 Ne7 11. f4 exf4 12. gxf4: This pawn exchange leaves white up one point.
moves.15. fxg5 fxg5 16. Bxg5 Nd7 17. Kc2 h6 18: Black opens himself to a knight/rook fork with 19. Qf6.
?  The knight just moved to threaten the rook (24. Ne6).  Rdd2 lets black attack white's a & h pawns, though a rook and pawn for a rook is not that great a trade when black is down a knight.  But 24.... b5 is just tossing away a rook for a knight.
moves.25. Rhf1: Ok, what?  Like, was there something wrong with 25. NxRd8?  That rook isn't going to sit there forever.
moves.25... Rxh2: ...or maybe it will.  Black seems determined to cast away his rooks.
moves.26. Bc7: 26 Bc7?  What was wrong with BxRh2?  Rook for pawn.  Great trade ANY day, and twice on Sundays.
moves.29... Kd7 30. Nc5+ Ke8 31. a4 bxa4 32. R: Actually, with the black king pinned against the wall white must push him into a corner or mate with the knight AND bishop.  This is more easily accomplished with the king, which probably requires taking out black's knight.  But I would ignore the black knight now and focus on getting the king into position.
moves.34... Ne7 35. Bd6 Nf5+: ?  PxN seems obvious.  I would have moved Nc8 here, to fork the bishop and rook.  Since the rook cannot protect the bishop, white loses the bishop for nothing.  Here black just loses the knight for nothing.
moves.36. Kf4: ???  What is wrong with PxN?  It was a free piece!  Now the bishop is wasted.
